title.rendered: New Online Event: Professor Naomi Baron, Reader Bot: What Happens When AI Reads — and Why It Matters

content.rendered:
We are excited to host an upcoming University of Cambridge ThinkLab/Intellectual Forum online conversation with Professor Naomi S. Baron on her new book, Reader Bot: What Happens When AI Reads — and Why It Matters.

Register for free here. 

🗓 Monday 23 February 2026
🕑 2:00–3:00 PM GMT
📍 Online (Zoom)

As AI tools increasingly scan, interpret, and summarise text for us, this session asks a timely question: What do we gain — and what might we lose — when we let AI read on our behalf?

Naomi Baron (Professor of Linguistics, American University) is a leading voice on language, reading, and technology, and her work speaks directly to current debates on literacy, learning, and culture in an AI-mediated world.

If you’re working in education, research, publishing, product design, or just curious about the future of reading, we’d love to have you join us.

Read more about Naomi’s book on the Stanford University Press website.

title.rendered: Build for Humans: The BBC Neural Commons

content.rendered:
How do we design technology that not only works, but feels genuinely good to use?

Join the BBC’s UX and Inclusive Design teams, together with researchers from Durham University Centre for Research into Inner Experience and the Cambridge ThinkLab, for an interactive session on the Neural Commons: a new approach to building emotional accessibility into products and AI.

We’ll explore why the attention economy is reaching its limits, what it means to design for trust, and how emotional experience is becoming a defining factor in the next generation of digital products.

Expect early insights, open discussion, and a look at the research shaping this work. Join us in-person at The Glasshouse Innovate Cambridge or online.

This event is open to anyone interested in shaping the future of digital experiences: product leads, designers, engineers, researchers, technologists, game developers and anyone exploring the intersections of UX, AI, ethics, and public-value technology.

title.rendered: ThinkLab & BBC Research Roundtable: AI, Accessibility & Neuro-inclusion

content.rendered:
How do we design technology that not only works, but feels genuinely good to use—especially for people with different cognitive and emotional profiles?

Join colleagues from BBC, Durham University (Centre for Research into Inner Experience), and University of Cambridge for a small, academic, discussion-led brainstorm on the Neural Commons: an emerging approach to building emotional accessibility into products, services, and AI.

This is deliberately interactive and exploratory. Expect short provocations, guided discussion, and lots of space to share examples, research questions, and critiques.

Location: Laurence Sterne Room, Jesus College Cambridge

We’ll workshop questions like:

  • What does it mean to treat emotional access as a real dimension of digital inclusion (not a “nice-to-have”)?
  • Where’s the line between supportive adaptation and emotional surveillance / profiling—and how should research + design frameworks guard that boundary?
  • How might systems support users through pace, tone, clarity, predictability, and interaction logic—without assuming a single “default” kind of mind?
  • What methods could help us evaluate “how it feels” to use a system (beyond standard usability metrics)?

    This session is aimed mainly at students and academics, but practitioners with a research mindset are very welcome.

Relevant areas include:

  • HCI / UX research, interaction design, human factors
  • disability studies, neurodiversity, accessibility, inclusive design
  • psychology, cognitive science, phenomenology, inner experience research
  • STS, media studies, digital sociology, digital policy / governance
  • public services & civic tech; workplace tech and organisational life

No prior expertise in “emotional AI” needed — curiosity and thoughtful questions are perfect.

title.rendered: Pixar Roundtable: Representating Neurodiversity in Media

content.rendered:
On November 8th, the University of Cambridge ThinkLab hosted an engaging roundtable discussion on the representation of neurodivergent individuals in media. This online event featured insights from leaders at the BBC and Pixar, both of which are at the forefront of promoting neuroinclusion and authentic representation in their work. Participants were given exclusive access to neuroinclusion-themed creative works, including Pixar’s poignant short film Loop (2020), which features an authentic non-verbal autistic character, and BBC’s Inside Our Autistic Mind documentary and the adaptation of A Kind of Spark. The panelists shared valuable lessons from these projects and discussed the broader media industry’s efforts to embrace neurodivergence fully.

Key themes of the discussion included the removal of ableist assumptions and stereotypes in media, the media’s role in promoting neuroinclusive practices, and the challenges neurodivergent individuals face within the industry. Panelists like Jessica Schibli, Head of Creative Diversity at BBC, and Nick Ransom, a neurodiverse journalist and consultant, provided insights on increasing diversity on and off the screen. Pixar contributors Erica Milsom and Krissy Cababa also shared their experiences in creating authentic representations of neurodiversity through their work on projects like Loop and Luca. The event underscored the importance of authentic representation, collaborative innovations, and active audience engagement in fostering a more inclusive media landscape.

Hacktivism and Black Creativity Lecture Series with George Hofstetter

content.rendered:
On February 7, 2023, Jesus College, Cambridge, hosted a significant event in partnership with Reddit and the University of Cambridge’s ThinkLab. The event featured George Hofstetter, the Founder and CEO of GHTech Inc., along with select members of his team and special guest lecturers. This event marked the beginning of a lecture series focused on “Black Creativity and Hacktivism,” aimed at inspiring students and faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to explore the intersection of disruptive innovation and social justice.

George Hofstetter, a globally recognized programmer, hacktivist educator, and CEO of GHTech Inc., led the event. He shared insights from his experience in building technology solutions that address social justice issues and empower marginalized communities. His work includes developing software that combats police brutality and creating culturally responsive curricula for underrepresented students. Attendees of the event, including computer science student Derrick Malloy from North Carolina A&T University,  stated ‘This is a program I will never forget. This was my first time attending a GHTech Inc. program and I was shocked and inspired by what they provided. Their lessons were so captivating, they reminded me why I was there in the first place.”

The event at Jesus College set the tone for a series of impactful discussions and workshops that aim to foster curiosity, encourage courageous dialogue, and build stronger communities through technology and innovation. GHTech Inc.’s approach, which combines inclusive design processes with a commitment to digital equity, was highlighted as a model for creating culturally relevant and socially responsive technological solutions.

AI and the Threat to Human Writing with Dr Naomi Baron

content.rendered: In May 2024, Professor Naomi Baron discussed how AI is reshaping writing and critical thinking, drawing from her book, Who Wrote This? How AI and the Lure of Efficiency Threaten Human Writing. Baron, an expert in linguistics, raised concerns about AI’s growing role in writing, suggesting that relying too much on it could erode our ability to think critically and creatively. Baron emphasized that writing is a process that helps us refine ideas, and by outsourcing this to AI, we risk losing a vital part of human cognition. While AI can be a useful tool for tasks like translation and generating content, she cautioned that its polished output might lead people to trust it without questioning, undermining the deep reflection writing requires. She also touched on AI’s impact on academia, with universities grappling with how to manage AI’s role in assignments and research. Ultimately, Baron urged that while AI has its advantages, we must protect the creative and reflective aspects of writing that make it uniquely human. Her insights highlight a key challenge in today’s AI-driven world: finding the balance between using technology to assist us and preserving the core human skills that define how we think and create.

Building a Second Brain for Writing with The Thesis Whisperer

content.rendered: For writers, researchers, and academics, the challenge of managing and organizing vast amounts of research can be overwhelming. In Building a Second Brain (for Writing), Professor Inger Mewburn, widely known as The Thesis Whisperer, shared powerful strategies to tackle this issue. Mewburn introduced the concept of “Building a Second Brain,” a system that helps store, organize, and retrieve information efficiently. The idea revolves around creating a reliable external storage system—whether digital or analogue—that acts as an extension of your mind, making research easily accessible whenever needed. She also explored the benefits and drawbacks of analogue (notebooks, index cards) versus digital systems (tools like Obsidian, Notion), offering participants the flexibility to choose what best fits their workflow. The session focused on optimizing writing productivity by implementing these note-taking techniques, ensuring that ideas and research can be seamlessly incorporated into writing projects. The overarching goal? Equip writers with systems that allow for smoother, more organized research and writing processes—ultimately enhancing productivity across the board.  If you’re struggling to keep your research organized and want to improve your writing process, this workshop provides actionable solutions designed to last for a lifetime of productivity.

How will AI Disrupt and Revolutionise Higher Education? A Conversation with Professor Bhaskar Vira

content.rendered: On June 2, 2023, ThinkLab hosted scholars online to explore how generative AI, like ChatGPT, is changing education. Led by Tyler Shores, the discussion highlighted both the exciting potential and ethical challenges of AI in learning. Professor Bhaskar Vira emphasized AI’s role in boosting personal learning, inclusivity, and adaptive feedback, while raising concerns about plagiarism and the complex question of originality. Dr. Inger Mewburn demonstrated how AI can streamline academic tasks like summarizing and brainstorming, likening it to a “calculator for words”—a helpful tool, but no replacement for deep, human creativity. Professor Susan Robertson took the conversation broader, discussing AI’s environmental impact and the exploitation of labor in its development. She urged the importance of critical thinking in how we use AI and warned against over-reliance on a single source of information. The takeaway? AI is here to stay, and universities need to guide students on using these tools responsibly. The future of learning will be shaped by how well we balance AI’s capabilities with the human skills that define true education.

Creating Supportive Neurodiversity Environments with Dr Temple Grandin

content.rendered: ThinkLab recently had the privilege of hosting Temple Grandin, a renowned expert in autism advocacy and animal behavior. In her talk, Grandin outlined key strategies for creating more inclusive environments for neurodiverse individuals, particularly in the workplace. She stressed the importance of a gradual transition from school to work and provided practical examples of accommodations that can have a significant impact. For instance, replacing lengthy verbal instructions with checklists can help autistic employees thrive. Her message was succinct: “Pilots use checklists, so why not us?” Grandin also emphasized the value of recognizing different types of thinkers—whether visual, pattern, or verbal—and encouraged schools and employers to harness these unique abilities. By acknowledging diverse cognitive styles, organizations can build more inclusive and effective workplaces. Ultimately, her insights underscored how small adjustments can unlock the full potential of neurodiverse individuals and foster supportive environments.

title.rendered: AI and Education(9)
The Joy of Not Knowing with Marcelo Staricoff

content.rendered: In February 2023, ThinkLab had the opportunity to chat with Marcelo Staricoff, who introduced The Joy of Not Knowing, his educational philosophy centered on embracing uncertainty as a catalyst for learning. Drawing on his experience as a head teacher and lecturer, Staricoff argued that confusion isn’t a barrier but a foundation for intellectual growth, encouraging learners to view the unknown as an exciting opportunity for discovery. He shared practical strategies, like using checklists instead of long instructions to support neurodiverse learners, particularly those on the autism spectrum, and emphasized the importance of recognizing different thinking styles—visual, verbal, and pattern-based—to foster inclusivity and innovation in schools and workplaces. In essence, Staricoff’s philosophy challenges the notion that certainty is the ultimate goal. Instead, The Joy of Not Knowing promotes curiosity, deeper understanding, and a mindset that embraces lifelong learning by tackling the unknown with confidence and creativity.

title.rendered: AI and Education(14)
The Email Urgency Bias with Laura Giurge

content.rendered: On February 1, 2022, the University of Cambridge ThinkLab hosted a webinar featuring Laura Giurge, a behavioral scientist from the London School of Economics, where she presented her research on “Email Urgency Bias.” This concept highlights a common workplace challenge: the assumption that emails require immediate responses, even when they are not urgent. Giurge’s research reveals a key disconnect—employees often feel pressured to reply quickly to emails received outside normal work hours, assuming that a delayed response may reflect poorly on their professionalism. However, the sender rarely expects an instant reply, which creates an unnecessary cycle of stress for the recipient. This misalignment, known as “email urgency bias,” can have significant negative effects on well-being, increasing stress and blurring the boundaries between work and personal life. One of Giurge’s key recommendations is for senders to explicitly state when an email is not urgent. By simply adding a note like “No rush,” senders can help reduce the anxiety recipients may feel and help promote healthier work-life boundaries. In her concluding remarks, Giurge emphasized the importance of creating digital norms around email communication. Tools like “delayed send” can help manage the flow of communication outside working hours, but the real solution lies in clear and transparent communication about expectations, fostering a more balanced and less stressful work environment.

Digital Interruptions – A Mindful Approach to Technology with Professor Gloria Mark

content.rendered:
In 2021, the University of Cambridge ThinkLab hosted Professor Gloria Mark for a talk on Digital Interruptions – A Mindful Approach to Technology. Professor Mark, from the University of California, Irvine, discussed how digital interruptions affect our ability to focus and multitask.

She explained that attention is goal-directed, but both external (like notifications) and internal (like wandering thoughts) interruptions constantly interfere with our focus. These interruptions shift not just our attention but also our goals, leading to increased mental load and stress. Her research showed that multitasking reduces productivity by creating “attention residue,” where part of the brain remains stuck on the previous task, slowing performance. Mark highlighted the concept of “kinetic attention,” a dynamic, alert state common in digital environments, and noted that while interruptions are often viewed negatively, they can provide valuable mental breaks if controlled. On average, people switch tasks every 47 seconds, often interrupting themselves as much as external sources do. To manage this, Mark advised identifying personal peak focus times, avoiding screen-switching, and balancing challenging tasks with mindless activities to maintain productivity and well-being. Her overall message was about finding balance in a distraction-filled world—understanding how to manage interruptions and knowing when to take breaks can improve both work performance and mental health.

Cambridge ThinkLab Hackathon: Shaping an Inclusive Future of Work

content.rendered:
Overview: A Leap Towards Inclusivity

Jesus College, the

Jesus College, the main gate.

In a world where neurodiverse individuals continue to encounter significant barriers in the workplace, targeted solutions remain scarce and fragmented. The ThinkLab Hackathon, a pioneering initiative held at Jesus College, University of Cambridge, on December 11-12, 2023, sought to change this narrative. Co-hosted by the University of Cambridge ThinkLab, Google Accessibility Discovery Centre, and BBC CAPE, this event marked a concerted effort to enhance representation and foster accessible, equitable work environments.

The Challenge of Underrepresentation

Despite an increasing awareness of neurodiversity, a significant gap remains in the representation of neurodiverse talent within the workforce. Traditional workplace environments often fall short in addressing the specific needs of neurodiverse employees, highlighting the vital necessity for innovative and inclusive solutions.
The Hackathon emerged as an effective response to this challenge, and created a collaborative space where diverse minds – from researchers and technologists to inclusivity experts and neurodiverse individuals – could converge. Their shared mission was to rethink and remodel workspace design to better align with the requirements of a neurodiverse workforce.

Innovation Through Collaboration

This joint effort marked a significant step forward in enhancing neurodiversity research and developing workplace practices that are more accessible and inclusive, illustrating a strong commitment to embracing diversity in professional settings.

Participants at the LEGO Serious Play Ideation Session, facilitated by Dr Monique Boddington.

Spanning two days,sthe event was packed with keynote speeches, breakout sessions, and collaborative team activities, all inspired by an ‘accessibility-first’ approach. This included quiet rooms, sensory aids, and clear navigational tools to cater to the varying needs of our participants. The diverse range of speakers, specialising in technology, inclusivity, neurodiversity, and workplace design, underscored the critical importance of such inclusive initiatives. Participants were organised into three interdisciplinary teams.
Access bracelets and fidget toys.
Each team democratically assigned roles and engaged in idea development, receiving guidance and mentorship from professionals across various sectors—including technology, media, finance, and academia—who have experience in working with diverse teams and creating inclusive workplaces.

Amidst the flurry of creativity and collaboration, the teams came up with three distinguished ideas and pitched their concepts to our jury, composed of industry professionals. The project Highlite captured third place with its open-source vision to experience sharing among neurodivergent employees, Neurodiversity Hero Game earned second place for its inventive approach to onboarding practices, and Embodied emerged as the clear winner with its creative and comprehensive approach to digital remote work platforms.

The Journey Ahead

Team photo of the Embodied team.

Recognition for these innovative efforts has already begun, with accolades being awarded to the teams for their creative contributions and the promising potential of their ideas. The team Embodied stood out, securing first place and a £5,000 cash prize, while the teams in second and third places received £2,000 and £1,000 respectively.
Building on the foundation of their initial concepts, each team is now poised to transition their ideas into tangible prototypes. With the support of ThinkLab and Cambridge Enterprise, this next phase will be characterised by a deeper exploration and realisation of their visions. Utilising the resources allocated for this purpose – which include funding for research reports, software specifications, and the creation of design models – the teams will have the opportunity to refine and develop their projects further.

Next steps

The ThinkLab Hackathon was more than just an event; it is, as we deeply believe, a symbol of our commitment to inclusive, neurodiverse-friendly workplaces. Looking ahead, the focus shifts towards guidance and development in collaboration with Cambridge Enterprise. We aim to explore potential applications and share our findings, while also supporting the teams in transforming their ideas into impactful products and services. Through these efforts, we hope to influence policy, crafting concise and insightful papers that provide actionable recommendations for embracing neurodiversity in organisations.
Finally, we cannot conclude this post without expressing our heartfelt gratitude to our judges and mentors, who travelled to Cambridge from various corners of the world and generously shared their professional insights with our participants. Special thanks go to the competing teams, as well as our own ThinkLab team and members of the Jesus College Intellectual Forum, who dedicated two entire days to this event despite a myriad of responsibilities. Their incredible creativity and team spirit made this event a transformative experience for everyone.

title.rendered: Progressing Neurodiversity At Work 2023: Online Conference ft. Tyler Shores

content.rendered:
In partnership with the Institute of Government and Public Policy, Cambridge Thinklab senior member Tyler Shores participated in this online conference discussing neurodiversity in the workplace.

 

Overview

Valuing neurodiversity is essential for creating and enhancing inclusive workplaces, recognising the importance of neurodiverse experiences, and supporting everybody to succeed and flourish.

Neurodiversity is an umbrella term including ADHD, autism, dyslexia, dyspraxia, Tourette syndrome, OCD and complex tic disorders. The majority of neurodivergent conditions may be invisible, yet without sufficient support, neurodivergent individuals will struggle in conventional workplace settings and are disproportionately discriminated against. Taking action to promote neurodiversity can unlock the talent of neurodiverse employees, strengthen workplace practices, acknowledge individual needs through flexible arrangements, and foster a positive culture where neurodiversity is accepted and celebrated.

Following the success of IGPP’s Progressing Neurodiversity at Work 2022 and Celebrating Neurodiversity at Work 2022 events, this event will examine the key barriers facing neurodivergent individuals in the workplace and the opportunities to overcome these in developing a supportive working environment. By broadening an understanding of neurodiversity, the event will explore the next steps to break barriers facing neurodivergent people in the workplace across a range of sectors and career stages. Through a range of open discussions and practical tips around workplace and communication practices, the event will feature the benefits of attracting, promoting, and retaining neurodivergent talent. The event will incorporate keynote presentations, case studies, and lived experiences, highlighting best practices in the workplace and their future progression.

The Science of Our Attention Spans with Professor Gloria Mark

content.rendered:
In January, the ThinkLab was thrilled to welcome Professor Gloria Mark to talk about her newly published book, Attention Span, and discusses how much of what we think we know about attention is wrong. She explores the current crisis of focus and productivity that is so deeply entwined with rising rates of anxiety and depression, and investigates what we might be able to do about it. Delving into the newly celebrated concept of ‘kinetic attention’, she introduces a more balanced understanding of the rhythm between deep focus and less focused states, which may actually serve to make us happier and more productive in the long term.

This event is hosted by the University of Cambridge ThinkLab and Gloria was joined by ThinkLab Manager Tyler Shores.

You can learn more about Gloria’s fascinating work at her website: https://gloriamark.com/

 

Discussion Summary

Dr. Mark, author of Attention Span: Finding Focus for a Fulfilling Life, tackled a challenge most of us face every day: how do we keep our focus in a world designed to distract us? During the talk, Dr. Mark broke down how our attention is being shaped—and often diminished—by the digital tools we rely on. From endless email alerts to the irresistible pull of social media, she revealed that our average attention span on a screen is now just 47 seconds. As our devices demand more of our time, we’ve become expert multitaskers, but at a significant cost: more mistakes, increased stress, and a drop in productivity. The solution isn’t to ditch our devices, Dr. Mark argues, but to learn how to manage them –  for instance, scheduling regular breaks to recharge and practicing “meta-awareness,” or recognizing when we’re mindlessly switching between tasks. She also suggested that workplaces implement “quiet times” to pause email and messaging, helping everyone regain control over their attention. By creating intentional spaces for focus, we can reclaim our ability to think clearly and live more fulfilling, balanced lives.

title.rendered: Book Talk: “Visual Thinking” by Dr Temple Grandin

content.rendered:
We are very excited to be welcoming back Professor Temple Grandin, one of the world’s most well-known and inspiring voices on autism and animal behavior online Tuesday, November 15th, 16.00-17.30 (GMT), as part of the ThinkLab. She will be speaking about her new book, “Visual Thinking: The Hidden Gifts of People who think in Pictures, Patterns, and Abstractions” (published on 13th October 2022).

Everyone is welcome to attend and free online tickets are available via this link. This will be an interactive event and Dr Grandin will try to answer as many questions for registered attendees as possible, so make sure you get your tickets early!

 

Cambridge ThinkLab Hosts: Temple Grandin on her new book Visual Thinking

Discussion Summary
Grandin discussed themes from her latest book, Visual Thinking: The Hidden Gifts of People Who Think in Pictures, Patterns, and Abstractions, highlighting the importance of neurodiverse minds in various fields. Grandin, an “object visualizer” herself, emphasized the different types of thinkers—visual, pattern, and verbal—and the need for these diverse perspectives, especially in hands-on industries like engineering and design. She stressed the importance of reintroducing vocational training in schools, particularly for students who excel in practical, mechanical tasks but may struggle with more abstract subjects. Drawing on personal anecdotes, Grandin shared how her unique thinking style led to her success in animal handling and design, encouraging attendees to embrace their strengths. The event wrapped up with a lively Q&A, where Grandin urged the audience to nurture neurodiverse talents and rethink education to better support all types of thinkers.

Research Seminar: ‘Is Social Media Making Us Lonely?’

content.rendered:
As part of the 2022 University of Cambridge Mental Health Awareness Week, ThinkLab Manager Tyler Shores is joined by Luke Fernandez and Susan J. Matt from Weber State University to discuss: is social media making us lonely?

Event description:

How often do you find yourself on social media during the course of a normal week? More importantly, how does using social media make you feel? Since the beginning of the COVID pandemic, the ways in which we have used social media has changed, as well as how we feel about social media in general. Social media is a paradox. It connects us in some ways, while pushing us apart in other ways. Social media has become our source of information, and a valuable means of connecting with friends and family, while at the same time making us feel lonelier and disconnected. In this talk, we will explore some of the research about social media, connection, loneliness – as well as looking at some ways that we might be able to helpful reframe our relationship social media in our everyday lives.

During Mental Health Awareness Week 2022, the University of Cambridge’s ThinkLab hosted an insightful virtual event titled “Is Social Media Making Us Lonely?” Led by Tyler Shores, with contributions from experts Susan Matt and Luke Fernandez, the discussion explored how social media affects our emotional well-being and whether it exacerbates feelings of loneliness. Shores opened the conversation by referencing research indicating that prolonged social media use can decrease well-being and intensify loneliness. He emphasized the phenomenon of “emotional distancing,” where interactions online, through features like “likes” and emojis, often replace more meaningful communication. While social media provides valuable ways to stay connected, it can lead to a superficial form of engagement, especially following the shift to digital communication during the pandemic. Matt and Fernandez offered a historical perspective, noting how attitudes towards loneliness have changed. Where solitude was once accepted as a natural part of life, modern society has come to view loneliness as a problem to be solved—often by technology. However, the panel argued that while innovations from the telephone to social media have promised solutions, they often create unrealistic expectations of constant connection. The event concluded with a call for more mindful use of social media. While the platforms themselves are not inherently harmful, it’s essential to understand how they can influence our emotional lives. Striking a balance between digital and real-world interactions is crucial for fostering deeper, more meaningful connections.

For more events, subscribe to the Cambridge ThinkLab YouTube channel here.

Full video:

 

Our Speakers:

Tyler Shores manages the ThinkLab research program at the University of Cambridge, and is a Senior Research Associate at the Intellectual Forum, Jesus College. His research focuses on digital habits, social media, and how digital environments shape how we work and think. Prior to Cambridge, Tyler worked in online education at Stanford, served as a director at an international education nonprofit organization, and worked at the Google world headquarters in Mountain View, California while running the Authors@Google program. His various work has been featured in the New York Times, BBC, WIRED, amongst others. And he was once on an episode of The Simpsons.

Luke Fernandez is Assistant Professor in the School of Computing at Weber State University where he teaches classes on the politics of technology and software development. He is co-author of Bored, Lonely, Angry, Stupid: Changing Feelings about Technology, from the Telegraph to Twitter (Harvard University Press, 2019). He holds a PhD in Political Theory from Cornell University. He is also a software developer. His articles have appeared in The Washington Post, Salon, Slate, and the Chronicle of Higher Education, among other places.

Susan J. Matt is Professor of History at Weber State. Her research focuses on the history of emotions and US social history. She is co-author of Bored, Lonely, Angry, Stupid: Changing Feelings about Technology, from the Telegraph to Twitter (Harvard University Press, 2019). She is author of Homesickness: An American History (Oxford University Press, 2011), and Keeping Up with the Joneses: Envy in American Consumer Society, 1890-1930 (University of Pennsylvania Press, 2003). Her writing has appeared in the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and the Journal of American History.

title.rendered: Research Seminar: Brad Aeon and Everything you always wanted to know about time management (but didn’t have time to ask)

content.rendered:
In 2022, the University of Cambridge ThinkLab hosted an online talk by Brad Aeon titled Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Time Management (But Didn’t Have Time to Ask). Aeon, an assistant professor at the University of Quebec in Montreal, shared insights from over a decade of research on time management, focusing on its historical roots, modern challenges, and misconceptions. Aeon began by tracing time management back to 8th-century Italian monasteries, where monks developed schedules and mechanical clocks to structure their days for spiritual discipline. He emphasized that, historically, time was often managed for people by societal structures like religion and work. Today, however, we have more freedom over how to use our time but face the increasing responsibility of self-management. Aeon explained that while popular time management books promise quick fixes, they often lack scientific backing. He argued that true time management goes beyond increasing productivity; it’s about aligning our use of time with our values, beliefs, and mental health. Aeon’s research revealed that managing time effectively is more closely tied to well-being and a sense of purpose than simply enhancing performance. He shared practical tools such as using schedules over to-do lists, breaking work into short bursts, and managing “slow multitasking” to improve focus and reduce stress. Aeon also advised prioritizing important but non-urgent tasks first thing in the morning, when willpower is strongest. The talk concluded with a Q&A, where Aeon addressed common challenges, like managing distractions, dealing with information overload, and balancing the demands of others. His overarching message was clear: effective time management is less about cramming more into our schedules and more about using time meaningfully and mindfully.

The Multi-Hyphen Academic with Dr. Isang Awah

content.rendered:
How can academics and researchers leverage their various skills, backgrounds, and passions to enable them to pursue their ideal career path? In this session, Dr. Isang Awah from Oxford University will speak about her own experience and there will be time for informal discussion and questions and answers. Isang was also a valuable contributor to the ThinkLab during her PhD at Cambridge!

ThinkLab Hosts Dr. Isang Awah (University of Oxford)

 

About our speaker: Dr Isang Awah is a Project Manager in the Department of Social Policy and Intervention at the University of Oxford. She works on the development of the Parenting for Lifelong Health Digital (PLH Digital), a digital version of the in-person parenting programme. Her research interests include social issues and literacy especially in developing countries and poor communities around the globe. She holds a PhD in Education at the University of Cambridge. She also holds degrees from Harvard University, U.S.A. and the University of Uyo, Nigeria. Isang is also a writer and film producer. As founder of MyRainbowBooks Limited, she introduced in Nigeria personalised storybooks that are tailored for African children and also initiated the nationwide annual creative writing competition for children in Nigeria.

More information on Isang can be found here: https://www.spi.ox.ac.uk/people/dr-isang-awah

For more events, subscribe to the Cambridge ThinkLab YouTube channel here.

Full video:

Dr. Awah, a researcher at the University of Oxford, shared insights on combining varied skills and passions to create diverse career paths. She explained the idea of a “multi-hyphen academic” as someone with multiple professional roles, like being a writer, researcher, and educator at once. Dr. Awah detailed her journey through degrees in biochemistry, literature, and education, as well as roles ranging from banker and film producer to nonprofit founder. A key theme was transferable skills—abilities that apply across fields, such as communication, project management, and problem-solving. She encouraged participants to recognize and leverage skills from all experiences, including volunteer work, when seeking new opportunities. Dr. Awah also discussed navigating societal expectations and emphasized the importance of pursuing personal passions. On balancing work and family, she highlighted the value of delegation and a strong support system. In closing, she urged attendees to stay curious, open to learning, and fearless in exploring new career paths, even without direct experience.
